&R5RS; Liberties and Violations
This section lists all ways in which &SISC; interprets the &R5RS; specification, where the standard is not particular clear. Such interpretations may allow non-portable code to be written and executed on &SISC; Additionally, all known &R5RS; violations are listed. Actual violations are considered &SISC; bugs, and have a high priority for being fixed.
2.3 - &SISC; allows identifiers to start with '+', '-', or '.' if they cannot be read as numbers.
2.3 - &SISC; uses the reserved characters '[' and ']' as synonyms for '(' and ')' respectively.
2.3 - &SISC; does not raise any warning or error when encountering the reserved characters "[]{}|", and allows "{}|" to appear in identifiers.
4.1.3 - &SISC; does not distinguish between () and the quoted empty list '().
5.3 - &SISC;'s syntax expander does not report an error when a new binding shadows a syntactic keyword. For example, (define define 3) does not produce an error.
6.2.3 - The standard desires that that operations such as sqrt try to provide exact results when given exact arguments. While &SISC; meets the requirement for sqrt, it is not clear what other mathematical functions should have this behavior. &SISC; takes no heroic efforts to meet this requirement.
6.2.6 - &SISC; allows radixes other than those specified in the contract for number->string and string->number. In particular, any radix up to 36 is allowed, and any unsupported value causes &SISC; to revert to base 10.
6.5 - The environment returned by the scheme-report-environment contains more bindings than specified in &R5RS;. This is a violation of the standard.
Runtime System Properties
Several Java System properties affect the operation of &SISC;. Below are the properties and their semantics.
minprecision
Specifies the minimum precision, in decimal places, to be maintained by the Quantity lib if using arbitrary precision floats.
maxprecision
Specifies the maximum precision, in decimal places, to be maintained by the Quantity lib if using arbitrary precision floats.
heapfile
Specifies the path to a &SISC; serialized heap file to use to initialize the interpreter's heap on startup. Overrides the default heap file.
emitannotations
Specifies the default value of the emit-annotations parameter (see ). If true, annotations will be enabled before loading any source files on the command prompt and will stay enabled until set via the emit-annotations parameter. If false, annotations will be disabled (the default).
